Kaxil Kiuic, A.C. manages the Helen Moyers Biocultural Reserve located in the Bolonchen District of the Puus Region of Yucatan, Mexico. The reserve is a living laboratory where research and education are carried out in an effort to not only acquire knowledge but help sustain the reserve's ecological and cultural resources. It is also a place designed to provide support to the neighboring Maya towns as they confront the challenges of sustaining their own culture and identity.

Micas-Kiuic Venture, A.C. owns the 4,000-acre reserve in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula where the Kaxil Kiuic Biocultural Reserve program is conducted. The reserve contains a wealth of archaeological sites important to the understanding of ancient and modern Maya culture. The Yucatan Program offers faculty and students a living laboratory where they study the relationships among disciplines as varied as biology, English, business, the environment, and archaeology. The Reserve - which demonstrates connections between economic development, environmental policy, and cultural preservation - has become a national model for interdisciplinary studies.

EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2019, THE OPERATING, LICENSE AND LEASE AGREEMENTS WERE SUBSTANTIALLY REVISED INTO NEW AGREEMENTS WHICH CHANGED THE REVENUE STREAM AND EXPENSES FOR THE ORGANIZATION. BELOW IS THE DETAIL OF THE ORIGINAL AGREEMENT IN PLACE THROUGH JUNE 30, 2019. EFFECTIVE AUGUST 1, 1992, THE CLUB ENTERED INTO A SUBLEASE AND OPERATING AGREEMENT WHEREBY THE CLUB AGREED TO SUBLEASE ITS PREMISES TO PREMIER FOOD SERVICES MANAGEMENT GROUP, INC., (PREMIER) WHICH OPERATES THE DINING AND CONFERENCE FACILITY AS THE "UCSD FACULTY CLUB" FOR $1 PER YEAR. IN 2005, THE CONTRACT WAS RENEGOTIATED, WITH TWO FIVE-YEAR EXTENSIONS BEGINNING JULY 31, 2008. THE AGREEMENT PROVIDED FOR THE CLUB TO RECEIVE 4.5% OF TOTAL UCSD FACULTY CLUB REVENUE AND 3% OF TOTAL CARRIAGE TRADE INCOME FROM THE CATERING ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE UCSD FACULTY CLUB. TOTAL REVENUES UNDER THIS AGREEMENT WERE $21,972 FOR THE YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2019. THE REVISED AGREEMENT ALSO PROVIDED FOR AN ANNUAL RENTAL FEE TO BE PAID BY PREMIER OF $25 AND PREMIER IS REQUIRED TO REPAIR AND MAINTAIN ALL REMOVABLE EQUIPMENT. IN ADDITION, AS OF JANUARY 1, 2004, PREMIER IS REQUIRED TO PAY AN ANNUAL MAINTENANCE FEE TO UCSD WHICH COVERS THE COST OF BUILDING AND GROUND MAINTENANCE. THE ORGANIZATION IS REQUIRED TO REIMBURSE PREMIER FOR ANY AMOUNT IN EXCESS OF $15,481, WHICH WAS $0 FOR YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2019. DURING 2014, PREMIER'S STOCK WAS SOLD TO SMG FOOD & BEVERAGE, LLC (SMG). HOWEVER, THE AGREEMENT REMAINED IN EFFECT AND WAS ASSUMED BY SMG. THE AGREEMENT WAS EXTENDED TO JULY 31 2018. HOWEVER, IN 2015, THE AGREEMENT WAS AMENDED TO EXTEND TO JULY 31, 2023. THE AGREEMENT WAS ALSO AMENDED TO PROVIDE FOR ANOTHER 5 YEAR EXTENSION. HOWEVER, ON JULY 1, 2019, THE AGREEMENT WAS TERMINATED AND NEW AGREEMENTS WITH UCSD AND CATERER WENT INTO EFFECT. AS PART OF THE NEW AGREEMENTS, SMG AGREED TO CONTRIBUTE $1.4 MILLION TO RENOVATE THE UCSD'S FACILITIES. THE CLUB ALSO AGREED TO FUND UP TO $139,280 OF THE RENOVATION BUT THE ACTUAL COST WAS $53,245 PAID IN PREVIOUS YEARS. UCSD ALSO PAID $50,412 FOR ADA UPGRADES WHICH IS CONSIDERED PART OF THE CLUB'S COMMITMENT. THE AGREEMENT ALSO CALLS FOR THE EXPANSION TO BE AMORTIZED OVER THE REMAINING 10 YEAR RENEWAL PERIOD. IF THE AGREEMENT TERMINATES PRIOR TO THE FINAL RENEWAL TERM OF JULY 31, 2028, THE CLUB IS REQUIRED TO REIMBURSE SMG FOR THE AMOUNT OF UNAMORTIZED CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THIS AGREEMENT AND ITS TERMINATION IN MARCH 2019, THE CLUB PAID SMG $1,570,745. UCSD REIMBURSED THE CLUB FOR THIS PAYMENT.

The Yucatan Program offers faculty and students a living laboratory where they study the relationships among disciplines as varied as biology, English, business, the environment, and archaeology. The Reserve - which demonstrates connections between economic development, environmental policy, and cultural preservation - has become a national model for interdisciplinary studies.

Founded in 1901 as St. Clara College in Sinsinawa, Wisconsin, home of the Sinsinawa Dominicans, Dominican University began as a women's college under the fundamental values that continue to guide the university today. Its rigorous education, diversity of thought, its commitment to social justice, and close mentoring of students to enable them to make a positive difference in the world. In 1922, the university relocated to its current location in River Forest, Illinois, where it was renamed to Rosary College. The new college rapidly expanded its curriculum and reach into the next decades establishing the nation's first study abroad programs, launching graduate programs and becoming coeducational. To reflect its stature as a respected, comprehensive and modern university, it was renamed to Dominican University in 1997. Today, Dominican is a premier Catholic University that ranks among the top masters' level universities in the Midwest. While maintaining its core Catholic identity, the University enrolls and mentors students of all faith backgrounds. Living out the ideals of founding sisters and those of Father Samuel Mazzuchelli, founding Father of the Sinsinawa Dominicans, the university is committed to giving compassionate service and to participating in the creation of a more just and humane world. Gifts received from the Sinsinawa Dominican Order in the Fiscal Year 2019-2020 was $69,850.
